page.title: 09The Grand Union Canal
page.content: This canal was built in the 19th century. It carried goods such as coal from the North. The coal would be taken to London to be used in the factories. Sand was also carried from the local sandpits. In the early 20th century the narrow gauge railway would carry sand from the nearby sandpits. It was taken to the canalside by small diesel trains and loaded onto the barge. Sometimes the barge towed another unpowered barge which was called a butty. This butty increased the amount that could be carried. The canal runs past Grove. There is a lock there called Grove Lock. It then runs past Tiddenfoot Leisure Centre, then carrying on to London, dividing Linslade and Leighton Buzzard. Water has eroded some of the unprotected banks and sand bags have been used to repair them.
